The basic concept of novelty search is to explore the space of behaviors =
in a particular domain. This is accomplished by rewarding individuals that =
display behaviors that are different from those seen prior in a search. 

I=
n contrast, fitness-based search will generally reward individuals accordin=
g to some fixed measure of progress. A significant benefit of novelty searc=
h when compared to fitness search is that novelty search is not generally s=
usceptible to the problem of "deception" where following the gradients of t=
he fitness function lead to dead-ends in the search space. Deception is the=
 reason that fitness functions must often be carefully crafted and tweaked =
in order to solve difficult problems.

Interestingly, sometimes exploring t=
he behavior space may lead novelty search to find the solution to a problem=
, though it was not directly trying to. Counter-intuitively, it may consist=
ently be faster at finding the objective than an objective-based search in =
deceptive problems.

Searching for behavioral novelty is different from an =
exhaustive search of the genotype space for many reasons. As you wrote, man=
y genotypes may map to the same behavior; novelty search may avoid many of =
these equivalent behaviors because once that area of behavior space has bee=
n thoroughly explored, it will not reward individuals displaying those beha=
viors, and will instead focus search on variations of genotypes that are de=
monstrating more novel behaviors.

In addition, the domain itself imposes l=
imits on behaviors; for example, physics constrains our behaviors, we canno=
t walk through solid objects. Further, demonstrating novelty may often requ=
ire learning about a domain. For example, to appear novel, a maze navigatio=
nal robot may need to learn about walls and how to avoid them . In fact, th=
is is what happens in the maze domain explored in the ALifeXI paper. So, no=
velty search may be in some sense about transferring information from the d=
omain into genotypes.

An exciting aspect of novelty search is that the sea=
rch is open-ended and can potentially continue endlessly finding novel beha=
viors that may grow in complexity. While a fitness-based search may have li=
ttle to do after it has solved a particular problem, novelty search can con=
tinue to find new behaviors even after it is has uncovered a solution.  

I=
 hope that this addressed some of your questions.
